definition: soldier/servant/to finish/to die/finally/at last/pawn in Chinese chess

sentences.english: Police say Chin appeared fine when guards brought breakfast to his cell.
sentences.chinese: 警方稱陳在獄卒給他送早餐的時候看上去一切正常。

sentences.english: The jailor brought up another livid prisoner.
sentences.chinese: 那個獄卒又帶來了一個面無人色的犯人。

sentences.english: He took with him several of his subordinates, and amongst them Dantès' jailer.
sentences.chinese: 他帶走了幾個下屬，看管唐太斯的獄卒也在其中。

sentences.english: One night, the gaoler decided to play a joke on his colleague to find out if.
sentences.chinese: 一天晚上，獄卒決定與他的同事開一個玩笑。

sentences.english: The jailor believed, and he and his family were baptized that very night.
sentences.chinese: 獄卒相信了，他和他的全家也都在那夜受洗。

sentences.english: The jailer came in the evening. Dantès was on his bed.
sentences.chinese: 傍晚時分，獄卒來了，唐太斯已上了牀。

sentences.english: In prison, there are wardens who are often sadistic. At work, they are called managers.
sentences.chinese: 監獄裏獄卒常常是虐待狂，在辦公室他們被叫作經理。
是那樣，那名獄卒承認道。

sentences.english: Just then, the gaoler appeared with the precious letter in his hands.
sentences.chinese: 就在這時，獄卒拿着那封珍貴的信出現了。

sentences.english: But he maintained his refusal in a way that impressed his Flemish jailers.
sentences.chinese: 但他拒絕放棄自己的觀點，其態度打動了佛蘭芒獄卒。

sentences.english: His jailers kept him by himself for one hundred eighteen days.
sentences.chinese: 他的獄卒由他自己保持的一百十八天他。

sentences.english: Enter duke, aegeon, gaoler, officers, and other attendants.
sentences.chinese: 公爵，伊濟安，獄卒，官吏等，及其他侍從等上。

sentences.english: I looked through the bars at my jailer.
sentences.chinese: 本人越過鐵柵看着獄卒。

sentences.english: One night, the gaoler decided to play a joke on his colleague.
sentences.chinese: 一天晚上，獄卒決定與他的同事開一個玩笑。

sentences.english: Just then, the gaoler appeared with the precious letter in his bands.
sentences.chinese: 這時獄卒上場，手裏拿着那封珍貴的信。

sentences.english: Two of guards vomited and half a dozen cats got killed eating vomit.
sentences.chinese: 兩個獄卒嘔吐後半打貓咪去舔嘔吐物被殺。

definition: lit. to punch and kick (idiom); to beat up/fig. determined to sort out a problem
to call loudly (idiom); to get people's attention/to make one's views known
to be furious/to fly into a terrible rage
to break the door down and enter (idiom)
to use violence (against sb)/to strong-arm sb/to manhandle
to shout and scream (idiom); to kick up a fuss/to make a scene
